articles.headline: Defiantly, Panasonic Pushes a Vast Catalog
articles.snippet: Critics say the Japanese manufacturer is losing markets to more focused and agile companies.
articles.abstract: Critics say the Japanese manufacturer is losing markets to more focused and agile companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Panasonic makes the world’s biggest 3-D television, a 152-inch, high-definition plasma screen that cost hundreds of thousands of dollars and is big enough to project life-size people.

articles.headline: In BP’s Record, a History of  Boldness and  Costly Blunders
articles.snippet: In pursuit of growth and profits, BP has taken risks and suffered consequences. But its record shows that it has been unable or unwilling to learn from its expensive mistakes.
articles.abstract: In pursuit of growth and profits, BP has taken risks and suffered consequences. But its record shows that it has been unable or unwilling to learn from its expensive mistakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Sarah Lyall, Clifford Krauss and Jad Mouawad and written by Ms. Lyall.

articles.headline: Chinese Factories Now Compete to Woo Laborers
articles.snippet: High demand for factory labor has emboldened workers, resulting in higher salaries and better treatment.
articles.abstract: High demand for factory labor has emboldened workers, resulting in higher salaries and better treatment.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZHONGSHAN, China — If Wang Jinyan, an unemployed factory worker with a middle school education, had a résumé, it might start out like this: “Objective: seeking well-paid, slow-paced assembly-line work in air-conditioned plant with Sundays off, free wireless Internet and washing machines in dormitory. Friendly boss a plus.”

articles.headline: Hefner Offers to Take Playboy Private
articles.snippet: Hugh Hefner offered to buy up the remaining third of the Playboy stock he does not already own for a sizable premium.
articles.abstract: Hugh Hefner offered to buy up the remaining third of the Playboy stock he does not already own for a sizable premium.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here’s something most people would not expect from Hugh Hefner: He wants to reveal less.

articles.headline: Automated Debt-Collection Lawsuits Engulf Courts
articles.snippet: As millions of Americans fall behind on bills, debt collection law firms have been clogging courtrooms with suits seeking repayment.
articles.abstract: As millions of Americans fall behind on bills, debt collection law firms have been clogging courtrooms with suits seeking repayment.
articles.lead_paragraph: As millions of Americans have fallen behind on paying their bills, debt collection law firms have been clogging courtrooms with lawsuits seeking repayment.

articles.headline: Design Flaw in iPhone 4, Testers Say
articles.snippet: Consumer Reports said it would not recommend the iPhone 4 because a hardware flaw in its antenna sometimes resulted in dropped calls.
articles.abstract: Consumer Reports said it would not recommend the iPhone 4 because a hardware flaw in its antenna sometimes resulted in dropped calls.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Did Apple make a lemon?
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: Abuse Took Years to Ignite Belgian Clergy Inquiry
articles.snippet: For decades, the nephew of the bishop of Bruges  sought to alert others that he had been molested by his uncle.
articles.abstract: For decades, the nephew of the bishop of Bruges  sought to alert others that he had been molested by his uncle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WESTVLETEREN, Belgium  Behind an aggressive investigation of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in Belgium that drew condemnation from the pope himself lies a stark family tragedy: the molestation, for years, of a youth by his uncle, the bishop of Bruges; the prelate’s abrupt resignation when a friend of the nephew finally threatened to make the abuse public; and now the grass-roots fury of almost 500 people complaining of abuse by priests.
articles.byline: By Doreen Carvajal and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: Beyond Guns: N.R.A. Expands Agenda
articles.snippet: The National Rifle Association’s defining battle has become a matter of settled law, so it has moved into other areas.
articles.abstract: The National Rifle Association’s defining battle has become a matter of settled law, so it has moved into other areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Fresh off a string of victories in the courts and Congress, the National Rifle Association is flexing political muscle outside its normal domain, with both Democrats and Republicans courting its favor and avoiding its wrath on issues that sometimes seem to have little to do with guns.

articles.headline: Paulson Likes What He Sees in Overhaul
articles.snippet: The former Treasury secretary wishes he’d had the tools in the financial overhaul bill when the crisis began.
articles.abstract: The former Treasury secretary wishes he’d had the tools in the financial overhaul bill when the crisis began.
articles.lead_paragraph: “The one thing you’re not going to get me to do is speculate.”

articles.headline: Iranian Scientist Emerges in D.C., but Mystery Only Deepens
articles.snippet: In the latest twist in a murky tale, a nuclear scientist who Tehran says was kidnapped by the C.I.A. took refuge in the Pakistani Embassy in Washington, Pakistan said.
articles.abstract: In the latest twist in a murky tale, a nuclear scientist who Tehran says was kidnapped by the C.I.A. took refuge in the Pakistani Embassy in Washington, Pakistan said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  An Iranian nuclear scientist who American officials say defected to the United States last year provided information about Iran’s nuclear weapons program and then developed second thoughts, walked into the Iranian Interests Section of the Pakistani Embassy here on Monday night and declared that he wanted a ticket back to Tehran.
